Ideally, the derived Markov chain probabilities could be directly compared to Monte-Carlo probabilities calculated using an NHL a scoring rate outcome sample population. For example, the set of $A$ NHL teams that had a scoring rate of $u$ at $n$ games and the subset of $B$ teams that subsequently had a scoring rate of $v$ at $n+m$ games could be counted, and the probability an NHL team reaches state $Sg^{n+m}=v$ given it was in state $Sg^{n}=u$ could then be estimated by $\frac{B}{A}$. The estimated probability could then be directly compared to $Pg_{i,uv,p}^{n+m}$.

Unfortunately, for most transitions, there haven’t been enough teams that reached the exact same final state from the exact same initial state for this direct comparison to be meaningful. Instead, I chose to allow a range of potential $u$ and $v$ values and recast the representative question as “If a team has a scoring rate in the range $u \pm \delta$ at $n$ games into its season, what is the probability it will have a scoring rate in the range $v \pm \delta$ at $n+m$ games into its season?”

Allowing for a tolerance $\delta$ in $u$ and $v$ results in the following method for estimating transition probabilities with NHL scoring rate outcomes: the set of $A$ NHL teams that had a scoring rate in the range $u \pm \delta$ at $n$ games and the subset of $B$ teams that subsequently had a scoring rate in the range $v \pm \delta$ at $n+m$ games could be counted, and the probability a team reaches a state $Sg^{n+m}=u$ in the range $u \pm \delta$ given it had a state $Sg^{n}=u$ in the range $v \pm \delta$ is then estimated by $\frac{B}{A}$. Define probability estimates made using this method as $NHL(u,v,n,m,\delta)$.

These estimates made using NHL scoring outcomes can then be directly compared to a tolerance-modified version of the Markov chain transition probabilities, which I define as

$$MC(u,v,n,m,\delta) = \frac{\sum_{z}\frac{e^{-n\mu}(n\mu)^{nz}}{(nz)!}\sum_{x=(n+m)v-nz-\delta(n+m)}^{(n+m)v-nz+\delta(n+m)}\frac{e^{-m\mu}(m\mu)^{x}}{x!}}{\sum_{z}\frac{e^{-n\mu}(n\mu)^{nz}}{(nz)!}}$$

where the domain of $z$ is the set of permissable values of $Sg_{i}^n$ in the range $u \pm \delta$ and $\mu$ is an approximation of the expected amount of scores earned in a game by the average NHL team, taken to be the average $SFg$ over the last 10 NHL seasons.

For example, in the last 10 NHL seasons there have been $52$ teams that had a $SFg$ in the range $3 \pm .1$ at $41$ games into their season. Of those teams, $19$ subsequently had a GFg in the range $3 \pm .1$ at $82$ games into their season. Therefore, the NHL scoring rate outcome transition probability estimate is $NHL(3,3,41,82,.1)=\frac{19}{52}=.365$, and the Markov chain scoring rate transition probability estimate is $MC(3,3,41,82,.1)=.357$.

I repeatedly pseudo-randomly generated 100 parameter sets $\theta = (u,v,n,m,\delta)$, calculated $MC(\theta)$ and $NHL(\theta)$ for each, and ran a linear regression between the two resulting sets of transition probabilities. The fit takes the form

$$MC(\theta) = \alpha NHL(\theta) + \beta + error(mean,variance)$$

where $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are constants and the error term is normally distributed. If $MC(\theta)$ were equal to $NHL(\theta)$ for every parameter set, then the fit parameters would be $[\alpha,\beta]=[1,0]$, the r-squared value would be $1$, and the error distribution would have a mean and variance of zero. Only a finite number of NHL games have been played, $\mu$ is only an approximation, and hockey is not a purely Poisson process, though, so both $MC(\theta)$ and $NHL(\theta)$ are expected to only be approximations of the true probability corresponding to the parameter set θ. As a result, some deviation of the data from the ideal fit parameters, an r-squared value less than 1, and non-zero error variance should be expected.

The average values of the fit parameters were found to be $[\alpha,\beta]=[0.994,.032]$, the average r-squared value was found to be $.887$, and the errors were approximately Normally distributed with a mean of zero and a variance of $.0082$. The parameter results are only point estimates, but the true parameters are in the ranges $0.923≤\alpha ≤1.065$ and $-.6002≤\beta≤0.066$ with $95%$ confidence. These results suggest that $MC(θ)$ is equal to $NHL(θ)$ plus noise resulting from the imperfect approximations made in calculating the two predictions.

insert figure 3 here

Residual analysis of the linear fit suggests that, while the relation between $MC(θ)$ and $NHL(θ)$ is not perfectly linear, the linear fit is a reasonable approximation. The success of the Markov chain equations in modeling NHL data suggests that modeling the NHL as a set of Markov chains with Poisson transition probabilities is reasonable.

entry.title: Uhh not sure tbh
entry.content:
1

Define conceiving of some thing as having it in temporary memory. Define knowing some thing as having it in permanent memory.

Assume that any time some thing is in temporary memory there is some probability it transitions to permanent memory - that any time some thing is conceived there is some probability it is acquired as knowledge.

Define an idea as any thing that can be conceived and acquired as knowledge. Define the set of all ideas as $I$ - all conceivable, knowable things are contained in the set $I$.

Define stimulating a thing as prompting the thing to conceive of an idea.

Define an experience as any thing that can stimulate. Define the set of all experiences as $E$ - all things that can stimulate are contained in the set $E$.

Define a living thing as any thing that is prompted by experiences to conceive of and know of ideas.

Assume that, at every moment a thing is living, it is being stimulated by some experience and conceiving some idea seeded by the experience.

2

Assume that not every living thing is equally likely to acquire an idea as knowledge once it is conceived. Assume that not every idea is equally likely to be acquired as knowledge upon conception by a living thing. Assume these are independent effects.

Assume that a living thing can be assigned a quantity describing how likely it is to acquire a conceived idea as knowledge on average. Assume that every idea can be assigned a quantity describing how likely it is to be acquired as knowledge upon conception by a living thing on average.

Define the quantity assigned to a living thing as the aptitude of the living thing. Define the quantity assigned to an idea as the difficulty of the idea.

3

Assume the probability that a living thing acquires an idea as knowledge upon conceiving it depends only on the aptitude of the living thing and the difficulty of the idea. Explicitly, assume the probability a living thing with aptitude $a$ acquires an idea of difficulty $d$ upon conceiving it is given by

$$p(a,d)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-(a-d)}}$$

Assume that every acquired idea constitutes an amount of knowledge corresponding to the difficulty of the idea. Explicitly, assume that acquiring an idea of difficulty $d$ earns a living thing quanta of knowledge equal to

$$q(d)=e^d$$

A living thing with aptitude $a$ which, stimulated by experiences, conceives of N ideas of difficulties $\vec{d}=d_1,d_2,...,d_N$ over its lifetime will then be expected to acquire an amount of lifetime knowledge $K$ equal to

$$K(a,\vec{d})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}p(a,d_i)q(d_i)=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{e^{d_i}}{1+e^{-(a-d_i)}}$$

These forms of $p(a,d)$ and $q(d)$ were chosen for simplicity, not because they resemble reality particularly well. The proper form might be an emperical question. The conclusions drawn below are particular to the assumptions made here.

4

Assume that the aptitude of a living thing is a random draw from a probability distribution. Explicitly, assume the aptitude of a living thing is a random draw from a normal distribution with a mean and deviation characterizing the subset of the set of all living things the living thing belongs to.

Assume that the difficulty of an idea is a random draw from a probability distribution. Explicitly, assume the difficulty of an idea is a random draw from a normal distribution with a mean and deviation characterizing the subset of the set of all ideas the idea belongs to.

Under these definitions and assumptions, the impact of changing the difficulty of available ideas on the accumulation of knowledge by living things, etc, can be easily approximated.

5

Here I consider a population of 100 living things characterized by a $N(X,1)$ aptitude distribution, where each living thing is assumed to conceive the same set of 100 ideas characterized by a $N(Y,1)$ difficulty distribution for $X$,$Y$ in $-1,0,1$

#collapse-hide

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import math
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import altair as alt

def prob_acquire(apt,dif):
    return math.exp(apt)/float(math.exp(apt) + math.exp(dif))

def knowledge_acquired(dif):
    return math.exp(dif)


#collapse-hide

num_ideas = 100
num_individuals = 100
idea_dif_std = 1
pop_apt_std = 1


choices1 = [-1,0,1]
choices2 = [-1,0,1]


plot_rows = []
for choice1 in choices1:
    for choice2 in choices2:
    
        pop_apt_mean = choice1
        idea_dif_mean = choice2

        individual_apts = np.random.normal(choice1,pop_apt_std,num_individuals)
        idea_difs = np.random.normal(choice2,idea_dif_std,num_ideas)

        individual_knowledges_acquired = []
        for apt in individual_apts:
            expected_knowledge_acquired = 0
            for dif in idea_difs:
                expected_knowledge_acquired += knowledge_acquired(dif)*prob_acquire(apt,dif)
            individual_knowledges_acquired.append(expected_knowledge_acquired)    
    
        for i in range(len(individual_apts)):
            row = [individual_apts[i],individual_knowledges_acquired[i],choice1,choice2]
            plot_rows.append(row)
            

plot_df = pd.DataFrame(plot_rows,columns=['Individual Aptitude','Individual Knowledge','X','Y'])


#collapse-hide

selection = alt.selection_single(
    name='Select',
    fields=['X', 'Y'],
    init={'X': 0, 'Y': 0},
    bind={'X': alt.binding_radio(options=choices1), 'Y': alt.binding_radio(options=choices2)}
)


alt.Chart(plot_df).mark_circle().add_selection(selection).encode(
    x='Individual Aptitude:Q',
    y='Individual Knowledge:Q',
    tooltip='Title:N',
    opacity=alt.condition(selection,alt.value(1.00),alt.value(0.00))
)

entry.title: Impact of Varying Wealth Inequality on Expected GDP Growth

link.title: Impact of Varying Wealth Inequality on Expected GDP Growth

entry.content:
This note explores the effect of varying wealth inequality on expected GDP growth in a simplified economy, under the assumption that consumer behavior is motivated by the local distribution of available consumption opportunities. First, I introduce a theoretical framework for estimating expected GDP growth given a distribution of wealth and a distribution of available consumption opportunities. Second, I apply the framework to explore how expected GDP growth varies with wealth inequality and distribution of opportunity.

Consider a simple economy with no taxes or subsidies, composed of M discrete units of wealth distributed among N economic agents. Taking the value-added perspective, the increase of the GDP of the economy over a time period $\delta t$ can be written as the total wealth added through productive processes by the agents during the time period $\delta t$.

$$\delta GDP=\sum_{i=1}^{N} p_{i}-c_{i}$$

Where $p_{i}$ is the wealth produced by the productive processes completed during $\delta t$ by economic agent $i$ and $c_{i}$ is the wealth consumed by the same agent in the the same processes. Assuming a constant, uniform return on investment $r$ such that $p_{i} = (1+r)c_{i}$, the growth can be written as

$$\delta GDP=\sum_{i=1}^{N} rc_{i}$$

Where the product $rc_{i}$ is the surplus value produced by economic agent $i$ during $\delta t$. Consequently the expected $GDP$ growth can be written as

$$E[\delta GDP]=r\sum_{i=1}^{N}E[c_{i}]$$

Assuming that the amount of wealth consumed by an economic agent during time period $\delta t$ is a random variable with a probability distribution characterized by the agent's wealth, such that the expected amounts consumed by agents of identical wealth are identical; and that an economic agent can only consume as much wealth as it has, expected GDP growth can be written as

$$E[\delta GDP]=r\sum_{w=0}^{M}N(w)\sum_{c=0}^{w} cP(c,w)$$

Where $N(w)$ is the number of economic agents having wealth $w$, the inner sum is over all possible amounts of wealth an economic agent of wealth $w$ can consume, and $P(c,w)$ is the probability that an economic agent with wealth $w$ will consume amount of wealth $c$.

Assuming that the probability an agent with wealth $w$ consumes an amount $c$ is the number of opportunities to consume amount $c$ relative to the total number of consumption opportunities available to an agent with wealth $w$, $P(c,w)$ can be written as

$$P(c,w) = \frac{O(c)}{\sum_{c=0}^{w}O(c)}=\frac{O(c)}{A(w)}$$

Where $O(c)$ is the number of opportunities to consume amount of wealth $c$, and $A(w)$ is the total number of consumption opportunities available to an economic agent of wealth $w$. The expected GDP growth is then

$$E[\delta GDP]=r\sum_{w=0}^{M}\frac{N(w)}{A(w)}\sum_{c=0}^{w}cO(c)$$

Given a wealth distribution $N(w)$ and an opportunity distribution $O(c)$, the expected GDP growth can be easily computed.
